text:
Hi guys, I'm Laura Vitale on this episode
of Laura in the Kitchen I want to show you
how I like to make a chicken parm meat loaf.

I shared a photo of my dinner not too long
ago on Instagram and I had everybody asking

me for the recipe so I'm going to share it
with you today, it's really easy and simple

but it's really delicious and great for company,
it's something that you can put together really

quickly and everybody loves it, if you love
chicken parm, which is the classic chicken,

bread, well bread and chicken or regular grilled
chicken with sauce and cheese, then this is

the perfect recipe for you and you can make
it for a lot of people in no time and no effort,

and there's no frying, there's not a lot of
bread going on so it's low carb, which I've

been getting a lot of questions from you about
wanting to see more low carb recipes and I'm
going to start sharing them with you.

But you do need a little bit of bread crumbs
to keep it all together, but for two pounds

of ground chicken or ground turkey, you only
need a half of a cup and it goes a long way.

Speaking of, let's go through the ingredients,
you need ground chicken or ground turkey,

make sure it's not ground chicken or ground
turkey breast, it's way too lean and not going
to give you enough flavor.

I've got a little bit of breadcrumbs and some
Italian seasoning, an egg, some onion and

garlic, I've got some pre-made marinara sauce
here, you can use store bought or homemade,

parmesan cheese and a little bit of salt and
you're also going to need some more sauce

and some shredded mozzarella for the very
end but not for right now.
I've got my oven pre-heated to 375F.
And I am ready to get going.
It comes together in like 5 minutes.

You just add everything in, so you've got
your breadcrumbs, and your Italian seasoning,

one egg, marinara sauce, this is going to
be flavor, and it's also going to help you.

Instead of adding an extra egg, I just like
to add a little bit of marinara sauce and

it makes perfect delicious juicy yumminess
of a meatloaf.

Then a good grating of parmiganno reggiano
- I'm actually going to use my coarse grater.
A good grating of that.

You want about a quarter cup maybe, but you're
also going to need some more for the top.

I'm going to grate in some garlic, you can
also go ahead and chop it, but if you've got

one of these rough graters, then two for one
because I'm also going to grate in some onion.

I love that onion flavor that you would get
from a lot of marinara sauce on your chicken

parm, but I don't want to chop it in here
because it'll be too coarse and I also don't

feel like sauteing it, so by grating it in
you get a little bit of that onion juice,

a little bit of that onion flavor, but without
any work whatsoever.

You just need about I would say a tablespoon
or so.

And then just a really good pinch of salt,
and then with your hands, you just go in and
you mix it all together until it's well combined.

Now, a meatloaf of this size, this is about
2 pounds of ground chicken, or ground turkey
whichever you choose to use.

It'll make a good six to eight slices, so
it goes a long way and I'm going to serve

it with - you can serve it with pasta of course,
you can serve it with cauliflower rice, you

can serve it with just simple green salad
and a loaf of baguette, I mean it's just really

a lovely dish that you can serve with company
or make it for just you and your husband,

you know you and your partner, or family and
keep the leftovers to make killer chicken
parm sandwiches.

But without the chicken parm, you're just
using a meatloaf, which is just as good if
not even better!

Okay, alright that looks good, I don't want
to over mix it.

Bring my baking sheet closer to me, I've got
a baking sheet with a little bit of olive
oil at the bottom just so that nothing sticks.

And now all that I'm going to do is just form
this into a meatloaf.
Just like so.

Okay, and then what I like to do because I'm
going to be topping this with some sauce,

I just like to run my fingers in the center
and kind of make a little divot in the center.
Like that.

That way the sauce holds better a little later
on.

Now a lot of people make meatloaf in a nine
by five inch loaf pan, I don't do that because

I find it a little bit difficult to cut the
meatloaf, and then especially if I'm using

beef, I like to do it on a baking sheet or
even a slotted baking sheet so that the grease

can fall through because if I don't do that
and I make it in a loaf pan, then the meatloaf

is swimming in its own fat and I don't want
that so if you've ever been curious as to

why I make my meatloaf this way instead of
a pan, which I've gotten those questions before,
now you know why!

Okay, this looks perfect and I'm going to
pop this into my oven which I have pre-heated

at 375F for about 45 minutes and I will show
you what it looks like when it's there.
Going to wash my hands first and pop it in.

I just took my meatloaf out of the oven, it
was in there for 45 minutes and now what I'm

going to do is I'm going to top it with some
marinara sauce, if it dribbles down the sides
that is perfectly fine.

I also have some extra that I'm going to serve
it with.
Just like that.

And then you can top it with provolone, Asiago,

Use whatever you prefer.

what to do.

Then I'm going to top it with some shredded
mozz.

you can do is you can put some breadcrumbs
